unit_learning_outcomes.description: Plausibly explain how and why Donald Trump won the 2016 Presidential election
Distinguish between competing interpretations of key US political issues, and succinctly express the strengths and weaknesses of these interpretations in written and oral form
Analyse and interpret primary and secondary US political sources and present the information in a written form
Articulate your knowledge of US politics in virtual discussions and understand the articulation between money, culture and power in US politics

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Reading in praparation for lectures on online participation.

enrolment_rules.description: 130cp at 1000 level or above OR (20cp in HIST or MHIS or POL or POIR or MHIX or POIX units at 2000 level)

assessments.description: This is a 2000-word essay +/- 10%, with topics drawn from across the unit, which allows students to explore a research topic in depth

The emphasis will be on discussion board participation exploring contemporary issues in US politics. Students will be assessed on the quality of their contributions, with a grading rubric being placed on ilearn so that students are clearer about the criteria on which they are being assessed.

The final exam for external students will be conducted over the weekend following the week (week 13). Students will write three short essays, drawn from topics across the entire unit. The emphasis will be on testing your knowledge in particular areas, though clear and concise writing will also be very helpful in demonstrating what you do know. The topics will be placed on ilearn by midday on Friday of the final week and should be submitted on Turnitin by midnight on the Sunday of that weekend.

This is a 1000 word essay +/- 10%, which will cover topics from the first month of the unit. Essay topics will be put on ilearn in week one, with more detailed instructions. Students must submit their essays through turnitin. Extensions will only be granted under the most exceptional of circumstances. All late work will be subject to the Arts Faculty's late submissions policy

data.description: US politics is today, as in much of its past, dominated by money and the power that money can buy. US cultural life is also preoccupied with money, in ways that profoundly affect the distribution of political power. Proceeding from these premises, this unit explores the relationship between money, culture and power in contemporary US politics. Topics covered include campaign financing, interest groups and the media; the impact of social inequalities of class, race, gender and sexual preference on US politics; the role of religion and political parties in the formulation of dominant political ideas; and the politics surrounding the global financial crisis and its aftermath.
